summary: This is an email chain from June 20, 2008, forwarding materials related to the Jeffrey Epstein case from attorneys Jay Lefkowitz and Kenneth Starr to John Roth at the Department of Justice. The attached documents include submissions alleging misconduct and responses to government letters, indicating legal advocacy on Epstein's behalf.

persons.name: John Roth
persons.context: Recipient of forwarded email and attached legal submissions from Epstein's defense attorneys; suggests waiting until Monday to call Jay Lefkowitz.

persons.name: Jay Lefkowitz
persons.context: Attorney from Kirkland & Ellis LLP, co-author of the submission to the DOJ regarding the Epstein case, seeking an in-person meeting.

persons.context: Sender of the initial email transmitting the legal submissions on behalf of Jay Lefkowitz and Kenneth Starr to John Roth.

persons.name: Stephanie Thacker

events.title: Submission of Epstein Defense Materials to DOJ
events.description: Epstein's legal team transmits a package of documents to the Department of Justice, including a Principal Submission, Summary of Misconduct, and responses to government letters.

keyFacts: On June 20, 2008, Epstein's high-powered legal team at Kirkland & Ellis LLP, including Kenneth Starr and Jay Lefkowitz, submitted a detailed package to the DOJ contesting the case against him.
The submitted documents included a 'Principal Submission', a 'Summary of Misconduct', and responses to letters from federal prosecutors (FAUSA) and another office (CEOS).
The email indicates direct, high-level communication between Epstein's defense and the Department of Justice regarding the pending case.
The correspondence is marked as confidential and attorney-client privileged, highlighting the sensitive nature of the legal strategy being deployed.
The subject line and content show the defense was actively advocating to the DOJ, potentially seeking to influence the prosecution's approach.
